preparation.prep_1_intro:
You get news that century long enemy in the Prerid Kingdom is planning to seize your Kingdom. However, due to a bad harvest season, the Kingdom is lacking in resources, so your only option are to raid nearby weaker Kingdoms.
You have been tasked with leading and documenting.

prep_1_dec_1.prompt: You are given a choice between sending new solider recruits into two different education paths. One focuses on range while the other focuses on close combat. Which education path do you send your first wave of soldiers?

answer_1.outcome:
Your soldiers become reliable with a bow.

STAMP 2 archers

answer_2.outcome:
your soldiers become skilled with a sword.

STAMP 2 swordsmen

prep_1_dec_2.prompt:
You are given a choice between two training programs. The first trains horses to battle alongside your soldiers, while the other trains the physical abilities of your soldiers. 
Which training program do you pick?

answer_1.outcome:
You can now have your best soldiers ride into battle.

STAMP 2 horses

answer_2.outcome:
Your soldiers become much more capable. Add the strength

STAMP to your army

prep_1_dec_3.prompt: You are given the option of bulking up your defense lines or bulking up your offensive lines with a grant from the local lord. Where do you put the money?

answer_1.outcome:
Your army grows impenetrable.

STAMP 2 Shieldmen

answer_2.outcome:
Your army strikes fear into enemies.

STAMP 2 swordsmen

prep_1_dec_4.prompt: Due to the poor harvest season, leather for shields and bows are limited. With what leather is given to the army, do you put it towards producing shields or producing bows?

answer_1.outcome:
Your kingdom's crest is burned onto the leather covers.

STAMP 2 Shieldmen

answer_2.outcome:
The leather is used to create a solid grip.

STAMP 2 archers

prep_1_outro.prompt:
It is now the time to pick your battle. Two Kingdoms are set before you, both with resources needed for your Kingdom’s protection. 
The first Kingdom of Vetedam resides in the flat fields, rich of crops and farm animals. They are known for their archery and speed, adapting to the open and flat geography.
The second, Comore Kingdom, rests on the rocky shores, rich in metals and oceanic resources. They’re known for their close combat and power, useful to living in the uneven geography.

answer_1.outcome:
It has been decided.

STAMP the enemy's crest in green

answer_2.outcome:
It has been decided. 

STAMP the enemy's crest in yellow

preparation.prep_2_intro: You’re hit with the news of the enemy Kingdom. They’re approaching steadily, and it’s unclear what their forces are made of. With time not on your side, you won’t be able to build an army by yourself. Having a helping hand is crucial. With little choices, you turn to the army who had fought with you.

prep_2_dec_1.prompt: You and the Hero are given a choice between two education paths for your new soldier recruits. One focuses on range while the other focuses on close combat. Which education path do you send your first wave of soldiers?

answer_1.outcome:
Your soldiers become reliable with a bow.

STAMP 2 archers

answer_2.outcome:
your soldiers become skilled with a sword.

STAMP 2 swordsmen

prep_2_dec_2.prompt:
Two training programs are brought between you and the Hero.
The first trains horses to battle alongside your soldiers, while the other trains the physical abilities of your soldiers. Which training program do you pick?

answer_1.outcome:
You can now have your best soldiers ride into battle.

STAMP 2 horses

answer_2.outcome:
Your soldiers become much more capable. Add the strength

STAMP to your army

prep_2_dec_3.prompt: You and the Hero are given the option of bulking up your defense lines or bulking up your offensive lines with a grant from the local lord. Where do you put the money?

answer_1.outcome:
Your army grows impenetrable.

STAMP 2 Shieldmen

answer_2.outcome:
Your army strikes fear into enemies.

STAMP 2 Swordsmen

prep_2_dec_4.prompt: Even with the resources looted from the Kingdoms, the amount of leather on hand is limited. With what leather is given to the army, do you put it towards producing shields or producing bows?

answer_1.outcome:
Your kingdom's crest is burned onto the leather covers.

STAMP 2 Shieldmen

answer_2.outcome:
The leather is used to create a solid grip.

STAMP 2 archers

prep_2_dec_king.prompt: The New King calls for a meeting with you, informing you of an apparent gap in your army line-up. Remembering the Raids of earlier, the New King insists on improving the army’s defense and speed. Sternly, he orders for you to add either more horses or more Shieldmen. Which option to do choose?

answer_1.outcome:
More recruits are trained to defend with shields.

STAMP 2 Shieldmen

answer_2.outcome:
Horses are added to the fleet for additional speed.

STAMP 2 horses

prep_2_dec_barbarian.prompt: The Barbarian calls for a meeting with you, informing you of a lack in your army line-up. Remembering the Raids of earlier, the New King insists that previous army was too weak and wasted time. Sternly, he orders for you to add either more Swordmen or more physical training. Which option to do choose?

answer_1.outcome:
New recruits are trained to mastery with a sword.

STAMP 2 Swordsmen

answer_2.outcome:
They physical training pays off. 

STAMP strength onto your soldiers

battle_1_decision_1.1.prompt:
You inform your army of the raiding of Vetedam, and you waste no time as your troops make the journey. 
You see the Kingdom from many miles away, visible with the flat openness of the fields. Your army faces the front entrance, guarded by the Kingdom’s own army of Archers.

STAMP an enemy Archer on the right side of cell in green ink

 Do you order your army to ambush and attack the enemy Archers before they have the chance to shoot, or do you sneak in through another entrance?

answer_1.outcome:
You order your army to ambush the guarding Archers. The enemy Archers see your army as you approach on the open fields, drawing their bows and shooting quick.
In the open fields, with no protection or ways of evading, the incoming arrows hits a large chunk of your troops. They’re weakened by these injuries.

STAMP arrows pointing left on the left side
STAMP weakness
answer_1.outcome_2:
You order your army to ambush the guarding Archers. The enemy Archers see your army as you approach on the open fields, drawing their bows and shooting quick.
With the speed and agility of the Horses, your troops are able to evade the in-coming arrows.

STAMP arrows pointing down on the left side

answer_2.outcome: You order your army to avoid the main entrance and sneak in through one of the outer entrances used for accessing the outer wheat fields. Through the tall wheat, your troops sneaks through, slipping in easily.

battle_1_decision_1.2.prompt:
You inform your army of the raiding of Comore, and you waste no time as your troops make the journey. You see the Kingdom as you approach, on the highest level of the rocky and uneven coastal terrain. It looks taller than it is, with high walls surrounding it. It’s clear there is only one entrance, as the other sides lead right into cliffside. It’s guarded by swordmen and shield men on the stone floor.

Do you order your army to charge or march to the entrance?

answer_1.outcome:
You order your troop to charge in for a surprise attack. However, the rocky and uneven stone ground is foreign on your troops feet. You watch as they each loose their footing and trip.
Unfortunately, your troops weren’t trained for this. Even with the horses, your men (and horses) are unable to recover from their trips. Your troops, scraped and hurt by the rocks, still continues to charge, but it’s clear they’re weak to their injuries.

STAMP Your army approaching the enemy walls
STAMP Weakness
answer_1.outcome_2:
You order your troop to charge in for a surprise attack. However, the rocky and uneven stone ground is foreign on your troops feet. You watch as they each loose their footing and trip.
Luckily, your troops were trained for this. Their physical training allowing your troops to quickly recover from the trip, brushing off their injuries and continuing to charge forwards.

STAMP Your army approaching the enemy walls
LOSE STRENGTH

answer_2.outcome:
You order your troops to march forwards, walking to avoid the rocky terrain. While taking their time avoiding injury, enemy troops take notice of your army and prepare to defend. 

STAMP your army on rocky terrain being noticed.

battle_1_decision_2.1.prompt:
Through the wave of arrows, your troops reach closer to the enemy Archers, now face to face with them. Now in close reach, your close range troops are able to attack. 
You’re given two options.

answer_1.option: Send your archers to raid the kingdom.
answer_1.outcome:
You follow along with your Archers, raiding one of the Kingdom’s inner towns, rich in wheat useful for food. This town has a large dried grain storage house, currently being raided by you and your Archers.

STAMP Using your Archer and House stamps

answer_2.option: Keep all your troops together to attack.
answer_2.outcome:
As your troops continue to fight the enemy soldiers, you see more enemy soldiers from inside the Kingdom start to approach, most likely alerted during the arrow rain. 

STAMP Your troops fighting the enemy's

battle_1_decision_2.2.prompt: Now inside, you decide to start raiding before enemies notice your invasion. Do you...

answer_1.outcome:
Deciding to keep your army together, your numbers are enough to start raiding a decently sized town within the Kingdom. 

STAMP your troops sneaking into enemy houses.

answer_2.outcome:
You decide to split your troops up into small group to cover more area. Following one of the larger groups, you find yourselves in a small town, with a small town center. 

STAMP your troops sneaking into enemy houses.

battle_1_decision_2.3.prompt:
Even with the struggle of the ground, your army gets closer to the enemies guarding the entrance. They don’t see you approach fast enough to use the rocks to their advantage, instead facing your troops at face level. They’re equipped with long swords and thick shields.
You’re given two options on how to advance.

answer_1.outcome:
You command your Archers to shoot at the enemy lines, hoping to use the slight distance between to your advantage. However, your arrows are no match for the shields, almost bouncing off. 

STAMP Your archers’ arrows being blocked by enemy shieldmen

answer_2.outcome:
You command your Shield-men to push through the enemy lines, using their shields to block the attacks of the swords. With your Shield-men on the defensive, your troops are able to force their way into the Kingdom.

STAMP Your troops fighting past enemy walls

battle_1_decision_2.4.prompt:
You order your troops to march forwards, walking to avoid the rocky terrain. As you get closer, the enemies sees your troop from the entrance, their Swordmen quickly scaling the entrance wall to gain the high ground.

STAMP Enemy swordsmen on the right side of the cell

answer_1.outcome:
You order your Archers to shoot at the enemy Swordmen. Unprepared for the long range attacks, your Archers land some fatal hits on them.

STAMP Enemy swordsmen being shot by your archers

answer_2.outcome:
You order your Swordmen to climb the wall to close the distance between. They begin to climb the wall with issue, as the enemy Swordmen are unable to reach. 

STAMP Your swordsmen facing the enemy swordsmen

battle_1_decision_3.1.prompt:
Enemy troops located inside the Kingdom gets news of your raiding, and a handful of Archers on horseback ambushes you in the storage house. 
Do you set the storage on fire, allowing for an escape but losing the grain inside, or do you use force to attack back?

answer_1.outcome:
You pull out a match stick from your pocket, striking it against one of the wooden support beam. You toss it into the piles of dried grain, seeing it catch a-blaze. As the fire starts to spread, it scares the enemy horses, allowing you and your Archers to escape the burning storage house.

STAMP your archers escaping the scene.

While none of your Archers looses their life, you are unable to continue to raid the town. The enemy Archers quickly recovers and their keen eye makes it impossible for you to continue to raid the town. It’s likely word has gone out as well, stopping your troops to raid anymore.

answer_2.outcome:
You order your Archers to fight back quickly. Your Archers, fast on their feet and bows, out-shoots the enemy Archers before they could ready their bows. Their horses are scared away from the arrows.
You and your troops are able to quickly raid the piles of grain from the storage. It’s enough grain to supply bread to your whole army.

STAMP Your army winning against the archers
answer_2.outcome_2:
You order your Archers to fight back quickly. Your Archers, injured from the arrows earlier, struggles to pull their bows in time. Your Archers are shot one by one, unable to defend themselves. You’re able to flee from the storage house.
Grouping back with the rest of your troop outside, you choose to draw back. The news have gotten out of your raiding, and more enemy Archers are making their way to the front entrance.

STAMP Your weakened archers failing to evade enemy fire

battle_1_decision_3.2.prompt:
They have yet to get within bow and arrow range. Your army won’t be able to combat all of them at once, so you have no choice but to send one of your force to take care of the incoming enemies.

 Who do you send in?

answer_1.outcome:
You order your Swordmen to take care of the incoming enemy troops. The Swordmen, jumping onto horseback, quickly charges at them, evading the arrows similar to before. They’re able to get face to face and attack, too close for the enemy Archers to shoot more. 
You see those enemy Archers fall as your Swordmen takes them out. Too far away to hear anymore commands, the Swordmen decide to do some raiding as you and the others continue to fight the enemy troops outside the Kingdom.

STAMP Your swordsmen’s triumph over the enemies
answer_1.outcome_2:
You order your Swordmen to take care of the incoming enemy troops. They make their way over, but with their injuries from the arrows earlier, they are slower and clumsier. The Swordmen get spotted easily, and lacking the speed, they get shot down easily.

STAMP Your swordsmen failing to evade enemy fire

Without a portion of your army, you’re unable to fight back against the wave of new enemies. With no other choice, you and your troops flee.

answer_2.outcome:
You order your Archers to take care of the incoming enemy troops. They quickly start to aim at those new enemies riding on horseback. Your Archers shoots once in range, taking advantage of their head start, as the incoming enemies are too focused on riding quickly to aim. You see those enemies fall as your Archers shoots them down.

STAMP Your archers firing enemies off horses

battle_1_decision_3.3.prompt:
After raiding the town, your troops gather in the town center, waiting for your next command. Before you can give any, you’re ambushed my a fleet of enemy soldiers. They’re quick, already aiming their bows at your men.
Who do you send first?

answer_1.outcome:
With little time, you send your Archers to take down the enemies. However, their speed fails to match your enemies, leading to some of your Archers to get shot and die. In good news, your Archers get a couple hits in, giving enough time for the rest of your troop to draw back. Even though you’ve lost some men, you return home with some resources.

STAMP Your archers being defeated by enemies on horses
answer_1.outcome_2:
Your Archers, quick on horseback, charge at the enemies. The speed and agility of your horses allows your men to evade the incoming arrows, as the enemies are too focused on your Archers to think about the rest of your troop. The Archers shoot down the enemies with no causalities on your side. 

STAMP Your archers on horseback defeating the enemies

 However, you see your men grow tired, and with the resources in hand, it would continue to be difficult to fight while holding such items. So, you decide to return home with your loot.

answer_2.outcome:
With little time, you send your Shieldmen to the front. With their shields, they defend the rest of your troops from the incoming arrows. However, this isn’t able to withstand much longer, as the waves of arrows start to weaken the shield.
Your offensive soldiers rush to attack the enemy Archers, but with a lack of speed, some of your Shieldmen fall before they your troops can attack. 
Your troops are able to push back against the enemies, just long enough for you to order a withdrawal. You have enough resources, and it would make fighting harder with less men and more carry ons.

STAMP Your army escaping among fallen shieldmen
answer_2.outcome_2:
Your Sheildmen quickly step to the front, defending the rest of your troops from the incoming arrows. With the enemy soldiers distracted, your offensive men jump onto horseback, taking advantage of the distraction to attack. The enemy soldiers fall one by one, until no more arrows threaten your Sheildmen. 

STAMP Your shieldmen blocking arrows for swordmen on horseback 

However, you see your men grow tired, and with the resources in hand, it would continue to be difficult to fight while holding such items. So, you decide to return home with your loot.

battle_1_decision_3.4.prompt:
As your group begin to start raiding, you’re ambushed by a small group of enemy troops, slightly more men than your group. They spot you first, already aimed to shoot.
Do you sacrifice your Shield Man or do you attack all together?

answer_1.outcome:
You send your one Shieldman to defend against the arrows. All the enemy soldiers laser focus on them, pelting them with arrows. Your Shieldman withstands the arrows until they start to wear-down, then break the shield. 
You and your group doesn’t stick around long enough to see them fatally shot, fleeing from the unequal fight without any resources. 

STAMP Your shieldmen’s last stand

answer_2.outcome:
You decide to take the risk and attack all together. Quickly, you realize you are no match for your enemies’ speed and tactics. Without order, one of your solider starts to defend, becoming a target for the enemy Archer’s arrows.
You and your group doesn’t stick around long enough to see them fatally shot, fleeing from the unequal fight without any resources.

STAMP Your army escaping, leaving one swordsman to hold them off
answer_2.outcome_2:
You decide to take the risk and attack all together. The first enemy arrow is shot at you, narrowly missing you and the horse stood besides you. It spooks the horse, causing it to yank itself out of the hold of one of your soldiers. Before you could grab onto the steed, it had already ran off towards the enemies, avoiding their arrows and kicking at their numbers. Not even the best trained men can defend against the back-kick of a horse.
In the chaos, you see the uninjured and living enemy Archers flee from the area. One of your soldiers is able to control the horse, and you quickly raid the town with what you can carry.
The horse still looked shaken up, so you decide to withdraw your army from the Kingdom.

STAMP The horse defeating enemies

battle_1_decision_3.5.prompt:
While your Archers were shooting, the enemy Swordmen charged quickly forwards, used to the unpredictable ground. They slash at your Archers, fatally wounding them.
With the loss of some of your men, you need to start raiding as soon as possible before the rest of your men grow tired.
Do you...

answer_1.outcome:
At your order, you send half of your troops to force their way through the entrance and disregard the enemy soldiers. At the sight of this, the enemy soldiers falter, confused at the sight. Your attacking troops take advantage of this and slaughter some of them. Your troops continue to fight as the others raid what they can.
After some time, with your troops still fighting at the entrance, your raiders return with some resources. They couldn’t get far, as their numbers were no match for the enemy soldiers within the Kingdom.

STAMP Your troops attacking enemies from both sides

answer_2.outcome:
At your order, your troops continue to fight despite the loss of some of your men. As they fight, they become more accustomed to the ground, able to start holding their own. With the physical training, your troops are able to reduce the enemies’ numbers significantly, enough to enter through the entrance.
You raid what you can, stone, fish, and ores, before needing to withdrawal as the enemy soldiers from inside the Kingdom makes themselves known. Before you leave the Kingdom land, your troops loot the fallen enemies' swords and shields

STAMP Your troops defeating the enemies on uneven ground.
answer_2.outcome_2:
At your order, your troops continue to fight despite the loss of some of your men. As they fight, it’s clear that they’re still unable to adapt to the terrain, and with the injures easily, they struggle to hold their own. You watch as some of your men die.

STAMP Your troops being defeated by the enemy

battle_1_decision_3.6.prompt:
Now inside, you see enemy troops within the Kingdom.
Do you...

answer_1.outcome:
You decide to fight the enemy soldiers you see. There are a lot more than you expected. While the physical training comes through in your troops, a couple do fall at the swords of the enemies.

STAMP Your troops fighting, some defeated
answer_1.outcome_2:
You decide to fight the enemy soldiers you see. There are a lot more than you expected. With their numbers and strength, and your army’s locational disadvantage, your men are easily slain. You’re barely able to flee from the Kingdom and return home, empty handed except for a lone surviving soldier.

STAMP Your army being defeated by the enemy

answer_2.outcome:
You decide to have your troops raid the Kingdom instead of fighting the enemies. They’re able to use the rocky geography to their advantage, evading the sight of the enemy soldiers within.
Out of sight, you’re able to raid successfully, gathering metals, ores, and preserved meats. With the raided loot and your men intact, you return home victorious.

STAMP Your troops sneaking and hiding from enemies

battle_1_decision_3.7.prompt: With less enemy Swordmen, their numbers are more manageable for your men. What are your next orders?

answer_1.outcome:
You decide to have your troops raid the Kingdom instead of fighting the enemies. They’re able to use the rocky geography to their advantage, evading the sight of the enemy soldiers within.
Out of sight, you’re able to raid successfully, gathering metals, ores, and preserved meats. With the raided loot and your men intact, you return home victorious.

STAMP Your troops sneaking and hiding from enemies

answer_2.outcome:
You decide to have your troops finish off the remaining enemies. Even with the lesser numbers of the enemy troops, their strength still poses a challenge for your men. You’re able to keep your ground, but some of your men fall at the enemies hands.

STAMP Your troops fighting the enemy, some defeated
answer_2.outcome_2:
You decide to have your troops finish off the remaining enemies. With your physical training, your men are able to slay what enemies were left at the Kingdom entrance. Now without opposition, your troops are able to raid successfully, gathering metals, ores, and preserved meats. With the raided loot and your men intact, you return home victorious.

STAMP Your strengthened troops victorious among defeated enemies

battle_1_decision_3.8.prompt: Now face to face with the enemy Swordmen, what are you next orders?

answer_1.outcome:
You decide to have your Shieldmen take over your Swordmen. Using their shields, they distract the enemy Swordmen, allowing for your troops to enter the Kingdom and start raiding.
During this however, some of your Shieldmen are slain by the enemy swords.

STAMP Your shieldmen fighting enemy swordsmen

answer_2.outcome:
You decide to have your Swordmen focus on fighting the enemies. The enemies troops, more stronger than your troops, are able to slay some of your Swordmen.

STAMP Your swordsmen fighting against various enemies, some defeated
answer_2.outcome_2:
You decide to have your Swordmen focus on fighting the enemies. With the help of their physical training, the enemies are unable to hold much ground, cornered against the walls. The enemy Swordmen don’t last long as they’re slain by your men.
With this, your troops are able to force into the Kingdom and start raiding.

STAMP Your strengthened swordsmen cornering the enemies

battle_1_outro_good.prompt:
Returning home from your conquest, you look over at your army. You see all your men returned safe. However, celebrations don’t last long.

You see two options before you.
The first is the New King, crowned by the Royal Counsel for their outstanding work during the Raids. They’re more calmer than the average soldier, slow to force but quick to strategize.
The second is what your Kingdom has dubbed the ‘Barbarian’, a title granted due to their physical and combat abilities. They’re strong and quick to fight, but slow to strategize.

answer_1.outcome:
And he is crowned. 

STAMP a troop of your choice, now with a crown among the surviving army

answer_2.outcome:
So it is decided. 

STAMP a troop of your choice, now with an axe among the surviving army

battle_1_outro_mid.prompt:
Returning home from your conquest, you look over at your army. Your army has dwindled, lost to hands of war. You don’t get much time for celebrators or memorials before receiving some news. 

You see two options before you.
The first is the New King, crowned by the Royal Counsel for their outstanding work during the Raids. They’re more calmer than the average soldier, slow to force but quick to strategize.
The second is what your Kingdom has dubbed the ‘Barbarian’, a title granted due to their physical and combat abilities. They’re strong and quick to fight, but slow to strategize.

answer_1.outcome:
And he is crowned. 

STAMP a troop of your choice, now with a crown among the surviving army

answer_2.outcome:
So it is decided. 

STAMP a troop of your choice, now with an axe among the surviving army

battle.battle_1_outro_bad:
Only one choice stands before you. The New King, crowned by the Royal Counsel for being the sole survivor of the Raids, praised for their resilience. They’re more calmer than your late soldiers, slow to force but quick to strategize. 

STAMP The new king, the lone survivor (any troop with a crown)

battle_2_decision_1.prompt:
Right as the last of your new troops are trained, you get new news. The enemy Kingdom are near, almost at your Kingdom’s doorstep.  You and the Hero quickly inform your troops of the incoming enemy.
When the enemy troops come marching, in sight of you, the Hero prompts you for your command.
Do you...

answer_1.option: Send all troop to defend the front entrance.
answer_1.outcome:
At your command, all your troops prepare to defend the entrance. With the experience from your last battle, your army is prepared for the fight. They’re able to hold the enemy troops back, even able to land some fatal hits.

STAMP Your troops defending your gate against the enemy

answer_2.option: Send Swordsmen to attempt a flank
answer_2.outcome:
At your command, your troops begin to set up a flank to attack the enemy from behind. To do this, some of your soldiers slip through other exits to catch the enemy by surprised. This leaves the front lines understaffed, resulting in the lost of some of your troops, mainly ranged and defensive men.

STAMP the enemies getting through your front lines

battle_2_decision_2.1.prompt:
The enemy soldiers start to back off slowly, but the Hero has the hunch that it’s not over yet. The hunch prompts you to make a decision.
Do you...

answer_1.option: Chase down the enemy soldiers backing away
answer_1.outcome:
You order your troops to chase down the enemy troops. They do as commanded, moving from their position to chase. With focus now on offense, your defense lessens. You loose some troops in the attack.

STAMP your army on foot chasing an enemy to the right
answer_1.outcome_2:
You order your troops to chase down the enemy troops. They do as commanded, moving from their position to chase. With the extra training, your troops are able to slay some of the retreating enemy soldiers.

STAMP Your troops attacking an enemy facing the right

answer_2.option: Keep your troops holding defences at the entrance
answer_2.outcome:
You order your troops to hold their defense of the entrance. You watch as the enemies back away until you can no longer see them. Before you start counting your victories, you hear the sound of your troops being attacked. With little time to react, some fall by the hands of the enemy troops.

STAMP enemies on the left side of the cell, attacking your troops from behind

battle_2_decision_2.2.prompt: With less troops defending your entrance, the enemy soldiers force their way in. You hear the panicked noises from the civilians inside. What are your next orders?

answer_1.outcome:
You quickly order your front line troops to protect the civilians. Your troops follow through, defending them from the attacks of the enemy army, almost too well. Before either you or the Hero realizes that the number of enemy soldiers had gone down, you get news that your Swordsmen sent for the surprise attack were intercepted. The result is the loss of your Swordmen, and a sizable portion of your army.

STAMP the enemy army on the left side of the cell, attacking your swordsmen on the right

answer_2.option: Attack to support the flanking Swordsmen
answer_2.outcome:
You quickly send an order for your Swordsmen to surprise attack now. The timing was perfect, catching the enemy soldiers off guard. In the shock, your troops are able to slay a large portion of the enemy forces. Before you can make your next order, the Hero steps in.

STAMP your archers and shieldmen on the left of the cell attacking enemies in the middle with your swordsmen flanking on the right

battle_2_decision_3.1_king.prompt:
You watch as your troops fight the enemies on the battle field a good distance from your Kingdom entrance. Both troops, your own and the enemy’s hold strong, neither faltering.
The New King urges for the enemies to be taken care of before your troops grow tired. They give two possible options. Either send in more horses or have your troops try to surround the enemies.

answer_1.outcome:
You command to release the horses. These horses have a burning hatred for the enemy Kingdom, and waste no time starting to kick and stomp on them. You’re slightly stunned by this, but decides a win is a win as the enemy troops’ numbers fall.

STAMP The enemy troops, trampled by horses

answer_2.outcome:
You command for your troops to reformate and surround the enemy troops. As they do this, the enemies prepare, and are able to stand their ground against the incoming attacks

STAMP Many enemies, defending against your troops

battle_2_decision_3.2_king.prompt:
The New King gives you two options.
The first is to split your troops up to narrow down on fighting specific targets, pushing them into the streets where they’re at a disadvantage.
The second is to send your Archers to split off from the rest, scaling the walls to use the distance advantage.
Which option do you choose?

answer_1.outcome:
You command for your troops to split up into small groups. Your troops fight hard, both thanks to numbers and training. The enemy troops are pushed into the Kingdom streets, but the fight continues strongly, with neither side wanting to face defeat.

STAMP A trio of your troops fighting evenly against enemies

answer_2.outcome:
You command for your Archers to climb the Kingdom walls. With the distance, your Archers are easily able to shoot down at the enemy troops, and evade the arrows shooting up. With this help, the enemy troops’ numbers fall fast.

STAMP Your archers firing at enemies from atop their wall

battle_2_decision_3.3_king.prompt: The King wants to call a surrender, but you have the option of faking it to surprise attack when the enemy’s guard is low. Which option do you pick?

answer_1.outcome:
You choose to surrender truthfully. The enemy commander accepts the surrender, sending the enemy soldiers to siege the governing body. Your troops are spared, but kept under watchful eye as the Kingdom is taken over.

STAMP your troops, surrendering to the enemy

answer_2.outcome:
You choose to fake surrender. The enemy commander accepts the surrender, sending some enemy soldiers to siege the governing body and some to keep an eye on your troops. The moment they’re sent off, you order your troops to attack with smaller enemy troop. However, it’s shut down quick from the enemies’ watchful eye. They aren’t merciful, severely wounding those who fought back.

STAMP Your troops, defended against by enemy shieldmen

battle_2_decision_3.4_king.prompt: The King urges the enemy commander to surrender, and seeing the numbers, the commander agrees and surrenders. The King lets you decide on accepting it or declining. Accepting would spare them, while declining would continue the fight.

answer_1.outcome:
You accept the enemy’s surrender. They don’t go back on their word, allowing themselves to imprisoned. With the enemy troops contained and defeated, you finally breathe easily.

STAMP enemy troops, surrendering to your army.

answer_2.outcome:
You decline the enemy’s surrender, ordering for your troops to finish off what enemy soldiers remain. The fight continues, the numbers leaning to your side.

STAMP your ruthless army, fighting against the few enemies left

battle_2_decision_3.1_barbarian.prompt:
You watch as your troops fight the enemies on the battle field a good distance from your Kingdom entrance. Both troops, your own and the enemy’s hold strong, neither faltering.
The Barbarian isn’t satisfied though, seeing this as a waste of time. He urges you to do something, either to let him handle it or tell your troop to focus on the enemies’ horses. Do you...

answer_1.outcome:
You let the Barbarian handle it, and they are ecstatic. They charge in, large sword swinging. Immediately, they break the formation of your troops, attack the enemies with little care. In the chaos, some of your men are slain and some of the enemies slip away and towards the Kingdom entrance. 

STAMP your barbarian, defeated as the battle continues

answer_2.outcome:
You command for your troops to focus on the enemy horses. Your troops, eager to finish off the enemies, quickly go for the horses. Slowly, as the horses are scared away or slain, the enemies are vulnerable to attacks. They don’t last long without their steed, and your troops are able to dismantle their army.

STAMP Your troops defeating enemies on horseback

battle_2_decision_3.2_barbarian.prompt:
The Barbarian gives you two options.
The first is to do a double flank, backing away and attacking from within the Kingdom.
The second is to inspire the Civilians to do their part in defending their Kingdom.
Which option do you choose?

answer_1.outcome:
You command for your troops attempt a double flank, but as they start to move away from the Kingdom walls, the enemy troops are already there to stop them. They easily predict your strategy, and swiftly start slaying your soldiers.

STAMP Enemy troops defending themselves from your troops attacking on both sides

answer_2.outcome:
In the distraction of the battle, the enemy troops don’t notice you and the Barbarian slip away into the Kingdom. You both stand in the town center, not too far from the Kingdom entrance. Together, you start to rally the frightened, scared, and angry civilians to help defend their beloved Kingdom from the enemies.
It works. The years of torment from the enemy Kingdom fueled a fire within your Kingdom’s people, and using whatever tools they have on hand, the civilians start to help the attack of the enemy army. It’s unexpected to your enemy, and they struggle to hold their own against the wave of angry people.

STAMP A chaotic battle, enemies on fire

battle_2_decision_3.3_barbarian.prompt: The Barbarian wants to keep pushing, either letting him handle it or have the troops continue to hold defence. Which option do you pick?

answer_1.outcome:
You let the Barbarian handle it. He does not, in fact, handle it well. He swings and attacks with little thought, and in the distraction, is taken down easily severely wounded by the enemy soldiers. Your own troops, stunned by this, are severely wounded as well.

STAMP the barbarian, failing to handle it

answer_2.outcome:
However, they don’t last long. Without the asset of physical training, their current strength is no match for the enemy’s numbers. They’re severely wounded one by one.

STAMP your troops, fighting a losing battle
answer_2.outcome_2:
With the asset of their physical training, they’re able to hold steady against the enemy’s numbers, putting up a strong fight.

STAMP your strengthened but outnumbered troops, fighting an even battle against the enemy

battle_2_decision_3.4_barbarian.prompt:
The Barbarian wants to finish off the enemy troops, years of distain for the enemy Kingdom showing in his eyes. He gives you the options of either sending everyone in to attack or to let him handle it.
Which do you choose?

answer_1.outcome:
You order for all your troops to attack the enemy soldiers, with the Barbarian adding ‘to finish them off’. With the numbers leaning to your side, your troops are easily able to slay the enemy soldiers.

STAMP your ruthless army, fighting against the few enemies left

answer_2.outcome:
You let the Barbarian handle it, and he is ecstatic. He’s able to focus in on the few remaining enemy soldiers and charge in swords swinging. The enemies have no chance, as the moment they notice the Barbarian, they’ve already been slashed. The enemy forces dies in a matter of seconds.

STAMP the barbarian’s rampage

battle.batlle_2_win:
As the fight continues, you watch as your Kingdom comes out on top, resisting the enemy Kingdom’s invasion. When the threat is gone, you finally celebrate. You watch as the Hero is celebrated, standing victorious .

STAMP your hero, standing among your army
battle.battle_2_lose:
As the fight continues, you watch as your Kingdom is seized, taken over by the enemy Kingdom. The Centuries of defending and work on holding them off crumbling in a matter of days. Your home Kingdom is no longer yours, but now an extension of Prerid Kingdom.

STAMP The enemy kingdom’s crest
